name: Ludacris
description:
'''Christopher Brian Bridges''' (born September 11, 1977), known professionally as '''Ludacris''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|uː|d|ə|k|r|ɪ|s}}, spoken as "ludicrous" in [[American English]]), is an American rapper and songwriter. Born in [[Champaign, Illinois]], Ludacris moved to [[Atlanta]], Georgia, at age nine, where he first began rapping. Starting out with a brief stint as a [[disc jockey|DJ]], he formed his own record label, [[Disturbing tha Peace]] in the late 1990s to independently release his debut studio album ''[[Incognegro]]'' (1999). After its single, "[[What's Your Fantasy]]" (featuring [[Shawnna]]), became a top 40 hit on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], the album was re-released by [[Def Jam Recordings]] as his major label debut, ''[[Back for the First Time]]'' (2000). The latter album peaked at number four on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and spawned his second top 40 single, "[[Southern Hospitality (song)|Southern Hospitality]]" (featuring [[Pharrell Williams|Pharrell]]).

Ludacris' following albums, ''[[Word of Mouf]]'' (2001), ''[[Chicken-n-Beer]]'' (2003) and ''[[The Red Light District]]'' (2004), were each met with continued success and received multi-platinum certifications by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). His fifth and sixth albums, ''[[Release Therapy]]'' (2006) and ''[[Theater of the Mind]]'' (2008), explored more serious subject matter than its predecessors. His seventh album, ''[[Battle of the Sexes (album)|Battle of the Sexes]]'' (2010) featured a return to the more lighthearted tone of his earlier albums. Throughout his career, Ludacris has scored two number-one singles on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 as a lead artist: "[[Stand Up (Ludacris song)|Stand Up]]" (featuring Shawnna) and "[[Money Maker]]" (featuring Pharrell), as well as three singles which did so as a guest performer: [[Usher (musician)|Usher]]'s "[[Yeah! (Usher song)|Yeah!]]" in 2004, [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]]'s "[[Glamorous (Fergie song)|Glamorous]]" in 2007, and [[Taio Cruz]]'s "[[Break Your Heart (Taio Cruz song)|Break Your Heart]]" in 2009. The following year, he guest featured on [[Justin Bieber]]'s single "[[Baby (Justin Bieber song)|Baby]]", which remains one of the [[List of best-selling singles in the United States#11× Platinum or higher|highest-certified singles]] of all time in the United States.

Ludacris is cited as one of the first [[Southern hip hop|Dirty South]] rappers to achieve mainstream success in the early 2000s. He is the recipient of three [[Grammy Awards]], a [[Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Award]], a [[Critics' Choice Movie Awards|Critics' Choice Award]] and an [[MTV Video Music Awards|MTV Video Music Award]]. Outside of music, he has portrayed the character [[List of The Fast and the Furious characters#Tej Parker|Tej Parker]] in the [[Fast & Furious|''Fast & Furious'' film series]]—first appearing in its second film, ''[[2 Fast 2 Furious]]'' (2003). His other notable acting roles include ''[[Crash (2004 film)|Crash]]'' (2004), ''[[Gamer (2009 film)|Gamer]]'' (2009), and ''[[New Year's Eve (2011 film)|New Year's Eve]]'' (2011). In 2021, he created and starred in the children's animated series ''[[Karma's World]]'' for [[Netflix]]. Ludacris is also a [[aircraft pilot|private pilot]].
